title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Who was the publisher that hired Denis Diderot to adapt the English cyclopedia for French subscribers in 1745?
What was the system used by Diderot to organize the work in the encyclopedia, based on Francis Bacon's "Classification of Knowledge"?

options.label: A
options.text: A two-part system based on memory and reason

options.label: B
options.text: A three-part system based on memory, reason, and imagination

options.label: C
options.text: A four-part system based on memory, reason, imagination, and commerce

options.label: D
options.text: A five-part system based on memory, reason, imagination, commerce, and technology

options.label: A
options.text: He praised the work and encouraged its dissemination

options.label: B
options.text: He declared readers excommunicated and wanted Diderot arrested on sight

options.label: C
options.text: He banned the work but allowed Diderot to continue writing

options.label: D
options.text: He had no response to the release of the encyclopedia

multiple-choice.question: How many articles did Louis de Jaucourt write for the encyclopedia?
What was the reason for Diderot's imprisonment in 1749?

options.label: A
options.text: He wrote an essay rejecting the divine right of kings

options.label: B
options.text: He wrote an essay about a philosopher's death bed rejection of God

options.label: D
options.text: He translated English works without permission

multiple-choice.question: How many volumes of text and illustrations did the encyclopedia comprise?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a testament to the absolute power of the French monarchy

options.label: B
options.text: It was a cornerstone of the Enlightenment and evidence of popular opinions migrating from pulpit and pew to cafe, salon, and press

options.label: C
options.text: It was a rejection of the principles of the French Revolution

options.label: D
options.text: It was a collection of recipes and had no broader significance

multiple-choice.question: In what year did the uncensored pages of the encyclopedia reappear in Russia?

options.label: B
options.text: They stayed indoors during peak sun hours

options.label: C
options.text: Their skin produced melanin as a natural sunscreen

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were exposed to less direct sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: Because they had a diet rich in vitamin D

options.label: D
options.text: Because they had a genetic predisposition to lighter skin

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of growing human cells in a lab?

options.text: To develop new treatments for diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To study how human cells function and understand how diseases develop

options.label: C
options.text: To create new human life forms

options.label: D

options.text: Due to a lack of nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: Because they had built-in control mechanisms that limited their division

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were not stored properly

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about HeLa cells that allows them to survive indefinitely?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are more resistant to disease

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: She donated her cells to science

options.label: C
options.text: Her tumorous cells were harvested without her knowledge or consent

options.label: D
options.text: She helped to develop the first vaccine using HeLa cells

multiple-choice.question: How have HeLa cells been used in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of radiation on human cells

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for diseases such as polio, measles, and HIV

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the behavior of normal human cells

options.label: D
options.text: To create new human life forms

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are able to develop into new human life forms

options.label: C
options.text: They are able to create new diseases

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to destroy other human cells

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They have shown that cervical cancer is untreatable

options.label: D
options.text: They have shown that cervical cancer is only treatable with surgery

title: Can you solve the temple riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

options.label: C
options.text: The expedition leader touched the inscriptions.

options.text: The giant sandglass was turned over.

options.label: A
options.text: Sending groups of four down two paths.

options.label: B
options.text: Sending one pair and two trios down the paths.

options.label: C
options.text: Sending all nine students down one path.

options.label: A
options.text: Because the possessed students might attack the others.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because the temple would collapse too quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the giant sandglass would run out of time.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reasoning behind trusting the report of a trio that returns in total agreement?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the possessed students would always lie.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the possessed students would always tell the truth.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are only two possessed students, and the other six will always tell the truth.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the trio would have the majority vote.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if each group gives a consistent answer?

options.label: A
options.text: The two possessed students are in separate groups.

options.label: B
options.text: The two possessed students are paired together.

options.label: C
options.text: Either everyone is telling the truth, or the two possessed students are paired together.

options.label: D
options.text: The expedition leader would have to guess who to trust.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if there's only one group arguing?

options.label: A
options.text: Both possessed students are in that group.

options.label: B
options.text: Both other groups must be telling the truth.

options.label: C
options.text: The expedition leader would have to trust the majority vote.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if there are two conflicts?

options.label: A
options.text: The possessed students are in separate groups, and the majority in both trios can be trusted.

options.label: B
options.text: The possessed students are paired together, and their report can be ignored.

options.label: C
options.text: The expedition leader would have to guess who to trust.

options.label: D
options.text: The temple would collapse, and everyone would be trapped.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the expedition's strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: The temple collapsed, and everyone was trapped.

options.label: B
options.text: The temple collapsed, but everyone escaped safely.

options.label: C
options.text: The temple didn't collapse, but the curse was not lifted.

options.label: D
options.text: The temple didn't collapse, and the curse was lifted.

title: Why are human bodies asymmetrical? - Leo Q. Wan

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the dust from the asteroid impact on plant life?

options.label: B
options.text: It had no effect on photosynthesis

options.label: D
options.text: It changed the color of plants

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the sudden disappearance of thousands of species due to massive changes in the environment?
What was the approximate percentage of species that went extinct during the mass extinction event between the Permian and Triassic periods?
What was the likely cause of the extinction of giant ground sloths, giant hyenas, and mammoths?

options.label: A
options.text: Climate change and ecosystem disruption due to melting ice caps

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of climate change and human activity

multiple-choice.question: What is the current rate of extinction compared to the normal background rate?

options.label: A
options.text: Similar to the normal background rate

options.label: B
options.text: 10-20 times higher than the normal background rate

options.label: C
options.text: Hundreds to thousands of times higher than the normal background rate

options.label: D
options.text: Lower than the normal background rate

multiple-choice.question: What can humans do to prevent mass extinctions?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue to exploit natural resources without regulation

options.label: B
options.text: Learn about past extinction events and use that knowledge to lessen our impact on other species

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore the problem and hope it goes away

options.label: D
options.text: Develop new technologies to control the environment

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the massive volcanic eruptions across Siberia during the Permian-Triassic mass extinction event?

options.label: A
options.text: A significant decrease in global temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: A dramatic change in ocean currents

options.label: D
options.text: A shift in the Earth's axis

multiple-choice.question: How have human tools and methods affected the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They have had no significant impact on the environment

options.label: B
options.text: They have allowed humans to adapt to the environment without changing it

options.label: C
options.text: They have become so effective that humans are actively changing the environment

options.label: D
options.text: They have only affected local ecosystems

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome if humans use their knowledge and abilities to mitigate their impact on the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass extinctions will continue to occur at an increased rate

options.label: D
options.text: Humanity's impact on the world can be transformed into a collaborative part of a biologically diverse future

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of Computer-Aided Design (CAD) software in engineering? (Factual Question)

options.label: B
options.text: To create and modify digital models of physical objects

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the structural integrity of buildings

options.label: D
options.text: To manage project timelines and budgets

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using 3D printing technology in product design? (Conceptual Question)
A company wants to develop a new sustainable packaging solution. Which design approach should they use? (Application Question)
What is the primary consideration when selecting materials for a product design? (Analytical Question)

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of factors including cost, sustainability, and functionality

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a prototype in the design process? (Factual Question)

options.label: A
options.text: To test the market demand for a product

options.label: B
options.text: To refine the design and identify potential flaws

options.label: C
options.text: To create a final product for mass production

options.label: D
options.text: To demonstrate the product's functionality to stakeholders

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a patent and a trademark? (Factual Question)

options.label: A
options.text: A patent protects intellectual property, while a trademark protects a brand's identity

options.label: B
options.text: A patent protects a brand's identity, while a trademark protects intellectual property

options.label: C
options.text: A patent is for inventions, while a trademark is for literary works

options.label: D
options.text: A patent is for literary works, while a trademark is for inventions

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of Human-Centered Design (HCD)? (Conceptual Question)

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a detailed description of the final product

options.label: B
options.text: To outline the project's objectives, scope, and timelines

options.label: C
options.text: To specify the materials and manufacturing process

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a wireframe and a mockup in user interface (UI) design? (Factual Question)

options.label: A
options.text: A wireframe is a low-fidelity sketch, while a mockup is a high-fidelity prototype

options.label: B
options.text: A wireframe is a high-fidelity prototype, while a mockup is a low-fidelity sketch

options.label: C
options.text: A wireframe is for mobile apps, while a mockup is for websites

options.label: D
options.text: A wireframe is for websites, while a mockup is for mobile apps
